elements.text: PART ONE
(Plastic or metal pieces are being clattered against each other whilst a recorded man's voice
lectures in the background.)

[OC]: I can assure you they foresee every possible variant. As you know, initial flybys of the Cimmerian system made it clear that it is rich in minerals and is uninhabited. In other words, ideal for mining and commercial exploitation without any adverse environmental and cultural side-effects which might fall foul of the code of the Galactic Charter of Species Protection.
Oh, what?
(laughs) Mister H wins again. Yes!
You're cheating. You have to be.
You can't cheat at draughts, Ferras.
Let me see the rule book.
There aren't any rules.
Oh, so you just make it up as you go along.
No, I mean there isn't a rule book. You just know how to play it. It's a noble tradition of the Haliard family. My great-great-great-great-great grandfather passed it down to my great-great
Great-great-grandfather's pet canary. Yeah, yeah, yeah. All right, Haliard, I can't take another one of your ancient and revered family routines.
Ooo, touchy, aren't we?
A klaxon sounds.
Airlock pressurisation in progress.
That'll be Orllensa.
No, really?
Bing!
That's her cooked.
Airlock opens.
Airlock pressurisation effective. Airlock pressurisation effective.
Outlook still chilly, is it, boss?
Orllensa is a slightly Eastern European or Russian sounding woman.
Freezing. And I don't think I'll ever get used to how dark it is out there.
Not for much longer, boss.
Ah, Ferras. Help me get out of this suit. I think my joints has seized up.
Sure.
Lots of unzipping.
And didn't I ask you to pay attention to that recording of Professor Astrov's instructions?
We have. Well, we did. I mean, we've heard it before.
You mean you've played draughts through it before.
Look, the EPUs are up to full power. That's all we need to know, isn't it.
Well
And you've checked their positions and aim.
Yes, but I did ask
Then we're safe to push the button, collect our money and (John Wayne) get the
hell off this rock, as the saying goes.
Why am I suspecting you two don't take me seriously as an authority figure.
Because we love you, Orllensa.
We love you.
(high pitched and twee) We love you, love you so much. (laugh)
Oh, all right. Switch the Professor off.
The recording stops. The men sigh.
Just shut up and power up, you two.
Powering up.
All energy projection units reading maximum capacity.
Alignment?
On the button. Mental countdown to getting the hell out of here begins now.
(John Wayne) Roger that.
Weird noise.
What the?
Orllensa, what's happening?
Alignment shift on central (unintelligible under noise and klaxons)
The whole place is shifting.
What? How can that be happening?
Yeah, how can this be happening? Aren't we talking unbreakable metal supports buried hundred of feet below the surface, that sort of thing?
Yeah, that was the sales pitch, yeah.
Oh, shut up, you two. External scanners are showing the foundations buckling.
Hold on!
What the hell's going on?
All cry out, then the noise suddenly stops. Echoing voices.
Everyone all right?
Yeah. Haliard?
No. Me arm. Ow!
My guess is that this is going to put your central EPU way out of alignment, Orllensa.
You don't say.
Creaking.
Oh no.
What now?
Main power levels falling fast.
The lights. Oh no. Please no.
Oh, my God. You're right. We're losing light. Ferras, emergency lamps, now.
Right.
Creaking.
Oh God, that's it. Shoot.
I can't see a thing.
Oh God, God, oh God. A planet with no sun, and the lights go out. This is not good!
Let's not panic, people. Ferras, the lamps should be in the locker to your left.
Ah! Got it. Hey, what are you doing over here? Orllensa?
I haven't moved.
But I, I felt something touch my arm. I. Oh no.
Emergency transmit. Emergency transmit. Where the hell are you? Got it.
Go, Orllensa, go, before the last drop of juice disappears.
Mayday, mayday, mayday. Recognition code 2307001600 O 100. Cimmeria Four Base. Loss of power. No light, structural damage. Come quickly. Help us. We're in the dark.
Orllensa!
Help us! What is it?
There's something in here with us. Listen. No.
(sibilant) Embrace the darkness.
Who are you?
Weird noise, Ferras screams.
You are safe. Safe forever.
The Tardis engines are running. A drink is poured and a spoon stirs. Rapid beeps.

What, what, what? Temporal energy discharge. Yes, temporal energy discharge. Temporal energy discharge consistent with energy signature Type Seventy Gallifreyan Time Capsules. What? A whole flotilla of them distinctly in my way. What are my fellow Time Lords up to now? Not like them to parade around the vortex in large numbers. Well, they don't seem to have noticed me. Perhaps I should say hello. One the other hand, do I really want to entangle myself in Time Lord red tape unnecessarily? Hmm. No. Anyway, it's probably just Rassilon's flag day or something. Yes, well, sorry, old chaps, love to join in and all that, but I was never one for crowds so I won't be joining the party. And although I'm sure you're pretty impressed with your shiny new Type Seventies, this old Type Forty still has a few tricks up her sleeve. Time to leave the party by the back door I think. Adios, amigos. Now, where was I? Oh, come on, old girl. Don't get temperamental on me.
Loud noises.
I suppose you're going to tell me it's absolutely necessary for you to be making all this noise?
Er, well, er. (noise changes, quietens) That's it!
I'm so glad.
Yes, the Tardis is getting a bit sticky on hover mode at the best of times, but the real indigestion started when I asked her nicely to incorporate a gentle temporal drift.
You should give her some health salts. So, what are we hovering over?
Time, Charley, time.
Ooo, very mysterious. What's that?
The Cimmerian system. Beautiful, isn't it?
Yes. Incredible colours. So bright.
Mmm. Then one day, it wasn't.
It wasn't? You mean it wasn't bright?
Yes. Or so the stories go.
How did that happen? What about that star?
It just disappeared.
That's horrible.
Mmm. I've always wanted to check up on the mystery of Cimmeria. What are you doing?
Demonstrating that I do pay attention some times.
Accessing the Tardis databank. Why, Miss Pollard, you never cease to impress me.
Yes, I'm not just an historical curiosity after all, am I. How are we spelling Cimmerian? S$ I
CIMMERIAN.
CIMMERIAN. Cimmerian. Of darkness. Of the Cimmeriae, a people fabled by the ancients to live in perpetual darkness.
It was named the Cimmerian system by Throxilian explorers after the sun apparently vanished. I've taken us back to a time when the star was still there, and now we're drifting forwards.
You want to find out what happened, don't you?
Well, it is a gap in my knowledge, yes.
Noise.
What's that?
Don't know. Meteors? A comet?
It's moving very fast.
That's because we're drifting forwards in time about half a century per second.
So it's actually moving quite slowly, whatever it is. They are.
They? Do you think so?
Well, I don't know. Looks like a lot of whatever they are, sort of flickering in the breeze. It's like watching the yachts coming back across the Solent at the Cowes Regatta.
Hmm.
Oh, it's gone. The sun's gone.
So that's when it happened. Better stop our drift and go back and have a look at it in real time.
Creaks of levers. Engines start.
That wasn't meant to happen.
We're landing, aren't we? In the middle of outer space.
I'm afraid so, Charley. Won't take a minute to get us drifting back again. Oh.
Is that oh, oh dear, or oh, oh good.
It's er, oh, I don't know.
Doesn't sound healthy.
No, er, I wonder if. Ow! Hold on!
I'm holding, I'm holding. (echoes)

Rescue Operational Security Module G723. Mission log update. On entry into the Cimmerian system, there was no further contact with the Cimmeria Four Base. Once in orbit around Cimmeria Four, I encountered an unidentified blue cuboid object, which did not conform to any known data on space vessels. Have matter-transported object into security holding bay. All security shields active and at maximum power levels. Object is proving impervious to full spectrum of scans. Still no response from Cimmeria Four Base. Interface with Cimmeria Four computer system protocols therefore not possible. It will be necessary to land on Cimmeria Four and investigate cause of mayday transmission. Final descent to planet Cimmeria Four on next orbital cycle.
A man is crying softly.
Haliard. Hal. Where are you, mate? I can't see you.
How could you? There's no light.
Orllensa! You scared the hell out of me. I didn't know you were there.
I could hear you.
Are you all right? Orllensa? I thought you'd been taken away. That they'd taken you.
No. All they took was the light.
[OC]: Is it safe out there?
Seems to be. Come on.
Tardis door opens and closes. Footsteps on metal.
Are we inside another spaceship?
Mmm, feels like it.
And that matter transmitter thing brought the Tardis here?
Matter transmitter, yes.
Like a wireless telegraph.
Yes, except it transmits people and things rather than dots and dashes.
Probably quite useful, I suppose.
Yes. Pretty heavy duty power output too. Caught the Tardis's forcefield off guard.
Who do you think transmitted Ow!
You all right?
Yes. What was that?
They've got us behind an energy barrier or containment shield of some sort.
The question is, who has?
Who indeed, Charley. Who indeed. But you can be sure they're watching us.
Oh, as if we're specimens in a jar, you mean?
Yes, fished out of a pond.
Let's hope it's not just some naughty schoolboy who's scooped us up.
What do you mean?
Well, you know what they do to insects they catch. Pull off their legs.
Urgh.
Haliard is still sobbing.
Why doesn't he stop that? Orllensa, why doesn't he stop crying? Stop crying, Haliard! Stop it! Why? Why won't he stop?
You know why, Ferras, don't you?
You mean, the pain?
Have you ever felt anything so terrible?
No, no, it paralysed me. I was, oh my god, oh no, no, please, I don't want to remember it. Oh, no. (cries)
I don't think I'll ever forget for as long as I live. But how long's that going to be?
Beep, beep. The computer activates.
Humanoid lifeforms from unidentified object under analysis. Phase one cellular analysis complete. Initiate interrogation protocol.
Heavy door slides open.
Hear comes trouble.
Don't be so pessimistic, Charley.
A machine beeps and clanks towards them.
You were saying? Big, metal and fierce looking. I don't think pessimism comes
into it.
Appearances can be deceptive.
Please be deceptive, please be deceptive.
Hello. Hello. This is Charley. I'm the Doctor.
Perhaps it's hard of hearing.

1: I am the Rescue Operational Security Module G723 Roving Assault Unit One. Be warned, I am equipped for full assault capabilities in all known hostile scenarios and am programmed for a variety of interrogation techniques.
Well, as I said, this is Charley.
1: Information logged. Repetition unnecessary.
Oh, sorry.
1: Explain your presence in the Cimmerian system.
Educational. Er, the Doctor wanted to know what happened to the sun. That's right, isn't it?
That's right.
Yes, that's right. Is that allowed? Did I say something wrong?
He seems to be thinking about it. Rescue Operational Security. Are you on a rescue mission? Who are you rescuing?
What does that mean?
1: Biohazard alert. Your cellular analysis has been assimilated.
We're not a biological hazard. Your analysis must be incorrect.

1: Rechecking. There is no mistake. Lifeform identified as Doctor, humanoid, bicardial, unknown species, no threat. Lifeform identified as Charley, humanoid, Terran origin, lifeform contains mutant cellular cultures inimical to life functions
Inimical!
Inim what? I hope you're not talking about me.
I don't understand.
1: Lifeform must be terminated.
What?
He's deactivated the holding shield.
Doctor, that's a gun, isn't it?
Wait. Please wait. Wait! Your information is incorrect. (sotto) Back to the Tardis, Charley.
1: Information is definite. Lifeform Doctor to be retained for further interrogation. Lifeform Charley to be terminated.
Ah! Doctor, he's put a forcefield around the Tardis.
1: Lifeform Charley, do not move. Lethal energy burst will be painless.
What?
1: Lifeform (speeds up.)
Run, Charley, run!
What are you doing?
Sonic screwdriver confusing his orientation centres with random sonic pulses. Won't last long. Run!
Where to?
Through that door! Anywhere! Just give me time to convince him you're not a threat. Go!
Right! Don't take too long, will you?
1: Error corrected. Lifeform Charley absent.
Yes, she just er, popped out for
1: Retrieving sonic device from lifeform Doctor.
Argh! That's my sonic screwdriver!
1: Analysing. Designed and built by highly sophisticated intelligence.
Oh yes, that's me. That's me. I'm highly sophisticated and intelligent, so I know what I'm talking about when I tell you that Charley is not a biohazard, and should not be terminated.
Are you claiming superior knowledge?
Ah, possibly.
(breathless) Where now?
Door clangs open.
Oh, no. Not another one.
You are implicated in an emergency situation. I cannot supply you with classified information.
Classified? I'm only asking to see the evidence which apparently proves my friend is a biohazard. Anyway, what is this emergency situation?
Cimmeria Four Base mayday signal. Subsequent loss of contact.
And now you think we're responsible?
There are no other lifeforms in this system.
Are you sure?
Oh, I've lost it. What? Oh, how many of these things are there? Please, Doctor, please, hurry up and convince them Oh!
Machine approaches.
Female humanoid biohazard located. Surrender yourself for termination. There will be no pain.
Somehow that's not much consolation.
Your obvious attempt to distract my attention has failed.
What do you mean?
You clearly do not appreciate that my programme core drives all roving assault units aboard this ship.
Ah. You mean there's more than one of you.
I am one. My parts are many.
Neatly put.
Lifeform Charley has been located and will now be terminated.
No! I have further information.
All information has been assessed. Action must be taken.
What kind of artificial intelligence are you if you're not interested in further information?
What information?
Suspend your termination order and I'll tell you.
Suspended. What information?
Information that will prove you're making a big mistake in killing lifeform Charley.
I am listening.
Show me she's still alive first, and keep her alive.
I believe you are making another attempt to distract
Carcinogens. Potentially carcinogenic cells. Cells that may grow into tumours.
Explain.
Show me she is still alive.
Beeps.
Charley!
[OC]: Doctor? Oh, my goodness. I can see you on this thing's face.
Yes, I can see you, too. Listen to me, Charley. Are you all right?
[OC]: Not really. It's another one of those things. It's got hold of me. I can't, oh, can't.
It's all right, Charley. He won't hurt you, will you.
Offensive functions are temporarily suspended.
[OC]: Temporarily?
Continue with your information.
Lifeform Charley comes from a time, a culture, that doesn't genetically modify itself.
[OC]: What are you talking about?

You see? She doesn't even know what I'm talking about. Access your historical database. You'll see that once upon a time, all human beings carried around all sorts of cellular impurities, potential diseases, abnormalities. They didn't modify embryos. They left it all to chance, nature's lottery. Let her go!
Accessing historical database.
[OC]: Doctor, it's loosening its grip.

He's thinking about it. You see, ROSM, those cells aren't a danger to others. One day they may harm lifeform Charley, but on the other hand they may well not. (sotto) Charley, I can see a door behind you. If he changes his mind.
[OC]: Where does it lead to?
(sotto) Never mind that, just use it if you have to.
[OC]: All right.
Your information is correct.
Thank you.
But my scans are also revealing other unusual information concerning lifeform Charley, beyond my analysis parameters.
What sort of information?
Unknown. The potential risk to Cimmeria Four personnel is therefore too great.
Charley, run!
Running footsteps.
Ascertaining line of fire.
Oh, how does this thing open? How does this thing open?
Clang. Hiss.
Ah! Ah!
Lifeform Charley has escaped into lifepod.
[OC]: Yes! Go, Charley, go!
Where on Earth am I?
Emergency automatic countdown.
Countdown to what?
Five. Four. Three. Two. One. Ignition. Purge.
Purge? Oh, no!
Lifepod ejected.
Where will it go?
It will automatically home on the nearest planetary body.
Which is?
Cimmeria Four.
Where your mayday signal came from.
That is correct.
Just as I thought. And your course?
Cimmeria Four. Lifeform Charley will be terminated when we make planetfall.
Not if I can convince you she's not a threat to your Cimmeria Four personnel.
My decision is irreversible.
Nothing is irreversible, my friend, not to the reasoning mind. You do have a reasoning mind, don't you?
My essential cerebral functions are faster and more complex that those of the human mind.
Well, you must be very nearly up to my standard, then. Well done. Will she be safe on Cimmeria Four?
There is no breathable atmosphere, but the lifepod will automatically with the airlock of the Cimmeria Four Energy Projection Unit Base.
Energy projection? Oh, never mind that. Will she be safe in the base?
An emergency situation would appear to be in progress. I can give no assurances.
You mean whatever's happened to the people on your base is going to happen to Charley.
Oh, no. What's that? Hello? What's happening?
Adjusting angle of descent. Planetfall in five minutes.
Planet? This is, this is a sort of lifeboat, isn't it, and I've been cut adrift. Oh, how am I going to get back to the Doctor? And more to the point, where is this thing taking me?
He's stopped. Orllensa. Orllensa?
Yes?
Oh, thank God. Can't you hear? Haliard's stopped crying.
Yes.
Haliard? Hal, old chum? You okay? Hal? Hal, mate? We're over here. Follow my voice. Come and join us, mate.
It's no use.
What do you mean, it's no use?
He's gone.
Gone where?
Where we're all going. Into the darkness.
Door clanks open.
This is the control deck. You may enter. The roving assault unit will be observing your every move, and additionally
You've put me into a containment field. Ow. Thank you.
We are now making final approach to Cimmeria Four Base.
What's that alarm mean?
External scanners are detecting unidentified particles in the Cimmeria Four Base, and I am not required to report all developments to you.
I know, but you've already established I'm a sophisticated intelligence, haven't you.
Yes, but your intentions are unknown.
I know, but it would hardly take you any extra processing power at all to keep me in the picture, now would it? After all, I might have some more interesting information for you.
Your input will be noted, but not acted upon.
I see. So what do we know about these particles you've detected, then?
Their nature is unknown.
Rather like me. And rather like me, they're intruders. Have they harmed the base personnel?
They are inhibiting scanner efficiency. I am unable to scan for lifeforms.
Oh dear.
Standard mission protocols demand that I initiate antibacterial measures to attempt dispersal of these particles.
Is that wise?
It is the only option available to me in the absence of any other information.
Oh.
Do you have any other information?
What's this, idle curiosity?
Please answer the question.
Er, no, I have no bananas today.
In the absence of an intelligible response, I shall proceed.
Good for you.
Activating particle dispersal beam.
Any news on lifeform Charley?
The lifepod is about to dock with the base.
Oh, Charley.
(Lifepod slows. Thunk! Engines shut down. Airlock door opens. Silence then slow footsteps on metal.)
Hello? Anyone there? God, it's dark. Hello? Who's that? I can hear you moving. Who's that?
[OC]: Who are you?
I'm Charley Pollard. Who are you?
[OC]: Ferras. Mike Ferras. I've got Orllensa with me. Where are you?
Where? Over here, in the doorway. Can't you see the light?
[OC]: Light? There is no light.
But, you sound as if you're in the same room as me. Surely you can see the light?
No.
No.
No, we can't.
Wait a minute, I can just make you out. Yes, a man and a woman. This way. That's right. You must be able to see me now.
No. But you sound so close.
I am. I'm looking right at you. Can't you see me?
They took away the light. How can you see us?
They? Who do you mean? But anyway, there's a light in this lifeboat thing I arrived in. Can't you see it? (pause) Oh, my God.
What? What is it?
I can see your faces. You, you don't know, do you.
Don't know what?
Your eyes.
What about them?
You've lost your eyes.

CIMMERIAN: (sibilant) Embrace the darkness.
ORLLENSA: Who are you?
CIMMERIAN: You are safe. Safe forever.
DOCTOR: What, what, what? Temporal energy discharge. Yes, temporal energy discharge. Temporal energy discharge consistent with energy signature Type Seventy Gallifreyan Time Capsules. What? A whole flotilla of them distinctly in my way. What are my fellow Time Lords up to now? Not like them to parade around the vortex in large numbers. Well, they don't seem to have noticed me. Perhaps I should say hello. One the other hand, do I really want to entangle myself in Time Lord red tape unnecessarily? Hmm. No. Anyway, it's probably just Rassilon's flag day or something. Yes, well, sorry, old chaps, love to join in and all that, but I was never one for crowds so I won't be joining the party. And although I'm sure you're pretty impressed with your shiny new Type Seventies, this old Type Forty still has a few tricks up her sleeve. Time to leave the party by the back door I think. Adios, amigos. Now, where was I? Oh, come on, old girl. Don't get temperamental on me.
CHARLEY: I suppose you're going to tell me it's absolutely necessary for you to be making all this noise?
DOCTOR: Er, well, er. (noise changes, quietens) That's it!
CHARLEY: I'm so glad.
DOCTOR: Yes, the Tardis is getting a bit sticky on hover mode at the best of times, but the real indigestion started when I asked her nicely to incorporate a gentle temporal drift.
CHARLEY: You should give her some health salts. So, what are we hovering over?
DOCTOR: Time, Charley, time.
CHARLEY: Ooo, very mysterious. What's that?
DOCTOR: The Cimmerian system. Beautiful, isn't it?
CHARLEY: Yes. Incredible colours. So bright.
DOCTOR: Mmm. Then one day, it wasn't.
CHARLEY: It wasn't? You mean it wasn't bright?
DOCTOR: Yes. Or so the stories go.
CHARLEY: How did that happen? What about that star?
DOCTOR: It just disappeared.
CHARLEY: That's horrible.

DOCTOR: CIMMERIAN.
CHARLEY: CIMMERIAN. Cimmerian. Of darkness. Of the Cimmeriae, a people fabled by the ancients to live in perpetual darkness.

CHARLEY: You want to find out what happened, don't you?
DOCTOR: Well, it is a gap in my knowledge, yes.
CHARLEY: What's that?
DOCTOR: Don't know. Meteors? A comet?
CHARLEY: It's moving very fast.
DOCTOR: That's because we're drifting forwards in time about half a century per second.
CHARLEY: So it's actually moving quite slowly, whatever it is. They are.
DOCTOR: They? Do you think so?
CHARLEY: Well, I don't know. Looks like a lot of whatever they are, sort of flickering in the breeze. It's like watching the yachts coming back across the Solent at the Cowes Regatta.
DOCTOR: Hmm.
CHARLEY: Oh, it's gone. The sun's gone.
DOCTOR: So that's when it happened. Better stop our drift and go back and have a look at it in real time.
DOCTOR: That wasn't meant to happen.
CHARLEY: We're landing, aren't we? In the middle of outer space.
DOCTOR: I'm afraid so, Charley. Won't take a minute to get us drifting back again. Oh.
CHARLEY: Is that oh, oh dear, or oh, oh good.
DOCTOR: It's er, oh, I don't know.
CHARLEY: Doesn't sound healthy.
DOCTOR: No, er, I wonder if. Ow! Hold on!
CHARLEY: I'm holding, I'm holding. (echoes)
ROSM: Rescue Operational Security Module G723. Mission log update. On entry into the Cimmerian system, there was no further contact with the Cimmeria Four Base. Once in orbit around Cimmeria Four, I encountered an unidentified blue cuboid object, which did not conform to any known data on space vessels. Have matter-transported object into security holding bay. All security shields active and at maximum power levels. Object is proving impervious to full spectrum of scans. Still no response from Cimmeria Four Base. Interface with Cimmeria Four computer system protocols therefore not possible. It will be necessary to land on Cimmeria Four and investigate cause of mayday transmission. Final descent to planet Cimmeria Four on next orbital cycle.
FERRAS: Haliard. Hal. Where are you, mate? I can't see you.
ORLLENSA: How could you? There's no light.
FERRAS: Orllensa! You scared the hell out of me. I didn't know you were there.
ORLLENSA: I could hear you.
FERRAS: Are you all right? Orllensa? I thought you'd been taken away. That they'd taken you.
ORLLENSA: No. All they took was the light.
CHARLEY: [OC]: Is it safe out there?
DOCTOR: Seems to be. Come on.
CHARLEY: Are we inside another spaceship?
DOCTOR: Mmm, feels like it.
CHARLEY: And that matter transmitter thing brought the Tardis here?
DOCTOR: Matter transmitter, yes.
CHARLEY: Like a wireless telegraph.
DOCTOR: Yes, except it transmits people and things rather than dots and dashes.
CHARLEY: Probably quite useful, I suppose.
DOCTOR: Yes. Pretty heavy duty power output too. Caught the Tardis's forcefield off guard.
CHARLEY: Who do you think transmitted Ow!
DOCTOR: You all right?
CHARLEY: Yes. What was that?
DOCTOR: They've got us behind an energy barrier or containment shield of some sort.
CHARLEY: The question is, who has?
DOCTOR: Who indeed, Charley. Who indeed. But you can be sure they're watching us.
CHARLEY: Oh, as if we're specimens in a jar, you mean?
DOCTOR: Yes, fished out of a pond.
CHARLEY: Let's hope it's not just some naughty schoolboy who's scooped us up.
DOCTOR: What do you mean?
CHARLEY: Well, you know what they do to insects they catch. Pull off their legs.
DOCTOR: Urgh.
FERRAS: Why doesn't he stop that? Orllensa, why doesn't he stop crying? Stop crying, Haliard! Stop it! Why? Why won't he stop?
ORLLENSA: You know why, Ferras, don't you?
FERRAS: You mean, the pain?
ORLLENSA: Have you ever felt anything so terrible?
FERRAS: No, no, it paralysed me. I was, oh my god, oh no, no, please, I don't want to remember it. Oh, no. (cries)
ORLLENSA: I don't think I'll ever forget for as long as I live. But how long's that going to be?
ROSM: Humanoid lifeforms from unidentified object under analysis. Phase one cellular analysis complete. Initiate interrogation protocol.
CHARLEY: Hear comes trouble.
DOCTOR: Don't be so pessimistic, Charley.
CHARLEY: You were saying? Big, metal and fierce looking. I don't think pessimism comes
CHARLEY: into it.
DOCTOR: Appearances can be deceptive.
CHARLEY: Please be deceptive, please be deceptive.
DOCTOR: Hello. Hello. This is Charley. I'm the Doctor.
CHARLEY: Perhaps it's hard of hearing.
RAU: 1: I am the Rescue Operational Security Module G723 Roving Assault Unit One. Be warned, I am equipped for full assault capabilities in all known hostile scenarios and am programmed for a variety of interrogation techniques.
DOCTOR: Well, as I said, this is Charley.
RAU: 1: Information logged. Repetition unnecessary.
DOCTOR: Oh, sorry.
RAU: 1: Explain your presence in the Cimmerian system.
CHARLEY: Educational. Er, the Doctor wanted to know what happened to the sun. That's right, isn't it?
DOCTOR: That's right.
CHARLEY: Yes, that's right. Is that allowed? Did I say something wrong?
DOCTOR: He seems to be thinking about it. Rescue Operational Security. Are you on a rescue mission? Who are you rescuing?
CHARLEY: What does that mean?
RAU: 1: Biohazard alert. Your cellular analysis has been assimilated.
DOCTOR: We're not a biological hazard. Your analysis must be incorrect.
RAU: 1: Rechecking. There is no mistake. Lifeform identified as Doctor, humanoid, bicardial, unknown species, no threat. Lifeform identified as Charley, humanoid, Terran origin, lifeform contains mutant cellular cultures inimical to life functions
DOCTOR: Inimical!
CHARLEY: Inim what? I hope you're not talking about me.
DOCTOR: I don't understand.
RAU: 1: Lifeform must be terminated.
CHARLEY: What?
DOCTOR: He's deactivated the holding shield.
CHARLEY: Doctor, that's a gun, isn't it?
DOCTOR: Wait. Please wait. Wait! Your information is incorrect. (sotto) Back to the Tardis, Charley.
RAU: 1: Information is definite. Lifeform Doctor to be retained for further interrogation. Lifeform Charley to be terminated.
CHARLEY: Ah! Doctor, he's put a forcefield around the Tardis.
RAU: 1: Lifeform Charley, do not move. Lethal energy burst will be painless.
CHARLEY: What?
RAU: 1: Lifeform (speeds up.)
DOCTOR: Run, Charley, run!
CHARLEY: What are you doing?
DOCTOR: Sonic screwdriver confusing his orientation centres with random sonic pulses. Won't last long. Run!
CHARLEY: Where to?
DOCTOR: Through that door! Anywhere! Just give me time to convince him you're not a threat. Go!
CHARLEY: Right! Don't take too long, will you?
RAU: 1: Error corrected. Lifeform Charley absent.
DOCTOR: Yes, she just er, popped out for
RAU: 1: Retrieving sonic device from lifeform Doctor.
DOCTOR: Argh! That's my sonic screwdriver!
RAU: 1: Analysing. Designed and built by highly sophisticated intelligence.
DOCTOR: Oh yes, that's me. That's me. I'm highly sophisticated and intelligent, so I know what I'm talking about when I tell you that Charley is not a biohazard, and should not be terminated.
ROSM: Are you claiming superior knowledge?
DOCTOR: Ah, possibly.
CHARLEY: (breathless) Where now?
CHARLEY: Oh, no. Not another one.
ROSM: You are implicated in an emergency situation. I cannot supply you with classified information.
DOCTOR: Classified? I'm only asking to see the evidence which apparently proves my friend is a biohazard. Anyway, what is this emergency situation?
ROSM: Cimmeria Four Base mayday signal. Subsequent loss of contact.
DOCTOR: And now you think we're responsible?
ROSM: There are no other lifeforms in this system.
DOCTOR: Are you sure?
CHARLEY: Oh, I've lost it. What? Oh, how many of these things are there? Please, Doctor, please, hurry up and convince them Oh!
RAU: Female humanoid biohazard located. Surrender yourself for termination. There will be no pain.
CHARLEY: Somehow that's not much consolation.
ROSM: Your obvious attempt to distract my attention has failed.
DOCTOR: What do you mean?
ROSM: You clearly do not appreciate that my programme core drives all roving assault units aboard this ship.
DOCTOR: Ah. You mean there's more than one of you.
ROSM: I am one. My parts are many.
DOCTOR: Neatly put.
ROSM: Lifeform Charley has been located and will now be terminated.
DOCTOR: No! I have further information.
ROSM: All information has been assessed. Action must be taken.
DOCTOR: What kind of artificial intelligence are you if you're not interested in further information?
ROSM: What information?
DOCTOR: Suspend your termination order and I'll tell you.
ROSM: Suspended. What information?
DOCTOR: Information that will prove you're making a big mistake in killing lifeform Charley.
ROSM: I am listening.
DOCTOR: Show me she's still alive first, and keep her alive.
ROSM: I believe you are making another attempt to distract
DOCTOR: Carcinogens. Potentially carcinogenic cells. Cells that may grow into tumours.
ROSM: Explain.
DOCTOR: Show me she is still alive.
DOCTOR: Charley!
CHARLEY: [OC]: Doctor? Oh, my goodness. I can see you on this thing's face.
DOCTOR: Yes, I can see you, too. Listen to me, Charley. Are you all right?
CHARLEY: [OC]: Not really. It's another one of those things. It's got hold of me. I can't, oh, can't.
DOCTOR: It's all right, Charley. He won't hurt you, will you.
ROSM: Offensive functions are temporarily suspended.
CHARLEY: [OC]: Temporarily?
ROSM: Continue with your information.
DOCTOR: Lifeform Charley comes from a time, a culture, that doesn't genetically modify itself.
CHARLEY: [OC]: What are you talking about?
DOCTOR: You see? She doesn't even know what I'm talking about. Access your historical database. You'll see that once upon a time, all human beings carried around all sorts of cellular impurities, potential diseases, abnormalities. They didn't modify embryos. They left it all to chance, nature's lottery. Let her go!
ROSM: Accessing historical database.
CHARLEY: [OC]: Doctor, it's loosening its grip.
DOCTOR: He's thinking about it. You see, ROSM, those cells aren't a danger to others. One day they may harm lifeform Charley, but on the other hand they may well not. (sotto) Charley, I can see a door behind you. If he changes his mind.
CHARLEY: [OC]: Where does it lead to?
DOCTOR: (sotto) Never mind that, just use it if you have to.
CHARLEY: [OC]: All right.
ROSM: Your information is correct.
DOCTOR: Thank you.
ROSM: But my scans are also revealing other unusual information concerning lifeform Charley, beyond my analysis parameters.
DOCTOR: What sort of information?
ROSM: Unknown. The potential risk to Cimmeria Four personnel is therefore too great.
DOCTOR: Charley, run!
RAU: Ascertaining line of fire.
CHARLEY: Oh, how does this thing open? How does this thing open?
CHARLEY: Ah! Ah!
ROSM: Lifeform Charley has escaped into lifepod.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Yes! Go, Charley, go!
CHARLEY: Where on Earth am I?
COMPUTER: Emergency automatic countdown.
CHARLEY: Countdown to what?
COMPUTER: Five. Four. Three. Two. One. Ignition. Purge.
CHARLEY: Purge? Oh, no!
ROSM: Lifepod ejected.
DOCTOR: Where will it go?
ROSM: It will automatically home on the nearest planetary body.
DOCTOR: Which is?
ROSM: Cimmeria Four.
DOCTOR: Where your mayday signal came from.
ROSM: That is correct.
DOCTOR: Just as I thought. And your course?
ROSM: Cimmeria Four. Lifeform Charley will be terminated when we make planetfall.
DOCTOR: Not if I can convince you she's not a threat to your Cimmeria Four personnel.
ROSM: My decision is irreversible.
DOCTOR: Nothing is irreversible, my friend, not to the reasoning mind. You do have a reasoning mind, don't you?
ROSM: My essential cerebral functions are faster and more complex that those of the human mind.
DOCTOR: Well, you must be very nearly up to my standard, then. Well done. Will she be safe on Cimmeria Four?
ROSM: There is no breathable atmosphere, but the lifepod will automatically with the airlock of the Cimmeria Four Energy Projection Unit Base.
DOCTOR: Energy projection? Oh, never mind that. Will she be safe in the base?
ROSM: An emergency situation would appear to be in progress. I can give no assurances.
DOCTOR: You mean whatever's happened to the people on your base is going to happen to Charley.
CHARLEY: Oh, no. What's that? Hello? What's happening?
COMPUTER: Adjusting angle of descent. Planetfall in five minutes.
CHARLEY: Planet? This is, this is a sort of lifeboat, isn't it, and I've been cut adrift. Oh, how am I going to get back to the Doctor? And more to the point, where is this thing taking me?
FERRAS: He's stopped. Orllensa. Orllensa?
ORLLENSA: Yes?
FERRAS: Oh, thank God. Can't you hear? Haliard's stopped crying.
ORLLENSA: Yes.
FERRAS: Haliard? Hal, old chum? You okay? Hal? Hal, mate? We're over here. Follow my voice. Come and join us, mate.
ORLLENSA: It's no use.
FERRAS: What do you mean, it's no use?
ORLLENSA: He's gone.
FERRAS: Gone where?
ORLLENSA: Where we're all going. Into the darkness.
ROSM: This is the control deck. You may enter. The roving assault unit will be observing your every move, and additionally
DOCTOR: You've put me into a containment field. Ow. Thank you.
ROSM: We are now making final approach to Cimmeria Four Base.
DOCTOR: What's that alarm mean?
ROSM: External scanners are detecting unidentified particles in the Cimmeria Four Base, and I am not required to report all developments to you.
DOCTOR: I know, but you've already established I'm a sophisticated intelligence, haven't you.
ROSM: Yes, but your intentions are unknown.
DOCTOR: I know, but it would hardly take you any extra processing power at all to keep me in the picture, now would it? After all, I might have some more interesting information for you.
ROSM: Your input will be noted, but not acted upon.
DOCTOR: I see. So what do we know about these particles you've detected, then?
ROSM: Their nature is unknown.
DOCTOR: Rather like me. And rather like me, they're intruders. Have they harmed the base personnel?
ROSM: They are inhibiting scanner efficiency. I am unable to scan for lifeforms.
DOCTOR: Oh dear.
ROSM: Standard mission protocols demand that I initiate antibacterial measures to attempt dispersal of these particles.
DOCTOR: Is that wise?
ROSM: It is the only option available to me in the absence of any other information.
DOCTOR: Oh.
ROSM: Do you have any other information?
DOCTOR: What's this, idle curiosity?
ROSM: Please answer the question.
DOCTOR: Er, no, I have no bananas today.
ROSM: In the absence of an intelligible response, I shall proceed.
DOCTOR: Good for you.
ROSM: Activating particle dispersal beam.
DOCTOR: Any news on lifeform Charley?
ROSM: The lifepod is about to dock with the base.
DOCTOR: Oh, Charley.
DOCTOR: (Lifepod slows. Thunk! Engines shut down. Airlock door opens. Silence then slow footsteps on metal.)
CHARLEY: Hello? Anyone there? God, it's dark. Hello? Who's that? I can hear you moving. Who's that?
FERRAS: [OC]: Who are you?
CHARLEY: I'm Charley Pollard. Who are you?
FERRAS: [OC]: Ferras. Mike Ferras. I've got Orllensa with me. Where are you?
CHARLEY: Where? Over here, in the doorway. Can't you see the light?
ORLLENSA: [OC]: Light? There is no light.
CHARLEY: But, you sound as if you're in the same room as me. Surely you can see the light?
FERRAS: No.
ORLLENSA: No.
FERRAS: No, we can't.
CHARLEY: Wait a minute, I can just make you out. Yes, a man and a woman. This way. That's right. You must be able to see me now.
ORLLENSA: No. But you sound so close.
CHARLEY: I am. I'm looking right at you. Can't you see me?
FERRAS: They took away the light. How can you see us?
CHARLEY: They? Who do you mean? But anyway, there's a light in this lifeboat thing I arrived in. Can't you see it? (pause) Oh, my God.
ORLLENSA: What? What is it?
CHARLEY: I can see your faces. You, you don't know, do you.
FERRAS: Don't know what?
CHARLEY: Your eyes.
FERRAS: What about them?
CHARLEY: You've lost your eyes.

elements.text: PART TWO
Your dispersal beam seems to be working, if I'm reading these displays correctly.
You are correct. But the dispersal rate is low.
Yes, I see what you mean. Those unknown particles are pretty densely packed, aren't they?
Lifeforms now detected.
I can't make out the imaging. Is that three or four?
Readings are still unclear. Unknown particle density is increasing.
Can't you increase power to the dispersal beam?
Not until landing has been effected. Initiating final descent.
(crying) My eyes! My eyes! Why did they do this?
Stop crying. Do you hear me? Stop it!
Sorry.
You'll end up like Haliard.
Haliard? Who's Haliard?
The darkness took him.
Took him? What do you mean?
I don't know what I mean! I've been driven half mad with pain. We both have. So that's how they did it. Burnt out our eyes.
The pain, it was indescribable.
This is horrible.
It is for us. At least you can see. Is it dark everywhere? Did they take all the light?
There only seems to be the light from that ship or whatever it is I arrived in. I can't see any other lights.
Noise
Wait a minute.
What is it?
I thought the light dimmed a bit just then.
Oh, no.
What do you mean, oh no?
(scared) It's happening again!
What's happening again?
They're taking your light, too.
Who? Who is taking my light? Ah! It just dimmed again. Orllensa, who did this to you? Who is taking the light?
I don't know. The Cimmerians, I suppose you'd call them.
Cimmerians? Fabled by the ancients to live in perpetual darkness. Ow!
What's the matter?
Oh, my eyes. I felt
Pain.
Ah! Oh, yes.
You have my pity, but there's nothing I can do.
Nothing you can do about ow!
Orllensa, I can't bear it. I can't bear to hear her!
It's all we can do. Listen to her pain.
Oh, oh, please no. Doctor!
Come on, come on, come on.
I find your impatience a curious response to the situation, lifeform Doctor, given you know I will terminate lifeform Charley when I have located her.
But surely your primary mission is to rescue the personnel of the base?
You are correct.

Isn't it obvious that these alien particles.are more likely to pose a threat? What you've detected in Charley is potential mutagenic cells which may or may not turn malignant in the next few decades. Which is the more clear and present danger?
Planetfall achieved. Particle dispersal beam intensity increasing to maximum. Lifepod is attached to secondary airlock. Extending docking connectors to Cimmeria Four Base main airlock.
Are you ignoring me?
There is still the matter of the unknown scan results. I'm considering my response.
Take your time, ROSM, old chap. Take your time.
Airlock connection achieved. Unknown particles now dispersed to minimal levels. You will accompany Roving Assault Unit One into the base.
Can I have my sonic screwdriver back?
I have analysed its capabilities and can now counteract them. You may have it back.
You're too kind.
Door opens. Footsteps.
Dark and foreboding. I'm beginning to feel right at home.
The RAU 1 wheezes up. ROSM speaks through it.
You will remain in the light of the entrance while I attempt physical interface with the base's computer systems.
Oh, back to Billy Goat Gruff, are we? Off you go, then.
RAU 1 leaves.
Charley! Charley, can you hear me? Charley? (sotto) Where are you?
RAU 1 returns.
Hmm, night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day stands tiptoe on the misty mountain top. Well done, ROSM, old chap. You got the lights working.
The computer systems were invaded by the same unknown particles. I have eradicated them.
Good for you. I'm off to find lifeform Charley.
You must wait here until the emergency situation can be assessed.
ROSM, my best friend could be in trouble, so if you want to keep me here, you're just going to have to shoot me.
Runs off.
That may yet be my preferred course of action, Doctor.
Running stops.
Charley! Charley, it's the Doctor! Are you all right? Charley!
Wailing.
Charley?
Laughing.
That's not Charley. Who is that? Hello?
Laughing continues.
We're here to help. Do you hear me? We're here to help. Listen to me. Listen, whoever you are.
Laughing stops.
All right, now. Now show yourself. It's all right, we're here to help. What happened here? Tell me. What happened?
The laughing is not entirely sane.
Embrace the darkness. Embrace the darkness. Embrace the darkness!
They have brought the light.
(The Cimmerians sound alike, and are only distinguished by which speaker their voices come from, left or right.)
2: Yes, they brought the light. They have destroyed our work.
They try to kill us. They bring light.
2: We must take it again.
We must.
2: Yes, yes, we must repair.
Yes, they must all embrace the darkness.
2: Embrace the darkness or die.
Footsteps.
Hello? Dear God. Charley! Charley, it's the Doctor.
Hello.
Oh. Hello. Was that you just now?
No. Haliard, I think.
A friend of yours?
Yes. You said you're the Doctor.
Er, yes. Yes, I am. Do you need a doctor?
I think I'm beyond that.
What do you mean?
Come closer.
Ah.
That's right. They took our eyes. The Cimmerians.
The Cimmerians? I wasn't aware of such a species.
Well, someone did this to us, didn't they?
Yes, yes, I suppose so. Listen to me. Have you seen?
Ha. You mean have I met your friend Charley?
You have?
Talked to her, yes. She arrived just before you did. Broke the news to us.
Broke the
Are you part of the rescue team?
In a way, yes.
Where's the ROSM unit?
Stomping around somewhere hereabouts. Can you take me to Charley?
I don't know.
Why not?
She was in pain.
In pain. Why?
It was her eyes. It was starting to happen again.
What was?
I don't know. I don't know. I don't know anything!
All right, all right, all right. I'm sorry.
No, I am. I find it difficult to think. I think I've gone insane.
I wouldn't be too sure of that, if I were you. I've spent most of my life being told I'm mad.
You're very kind. Your friend Charley. She ran. I don't know how far. I can take you back to the secondary airlock reception, where we were. I think.
Secondary airlock. We'll follow the signs. Take my arm, er, what's your name?
Orllensa.
Orllensa, take my arm. So, come on.
Oh. Oh. What happened? Where? Who are you?
Haliard laughs.
Who are you? I can't make out your face.
But you can see.
Not very well. My eyes hurt.
Then they didn't succeed this time. But don't worry, they'll be back.
Who? You mean the Cimmerians? Have you seen them?
You don't see them. Don't you understand? They take the light.
Are you Haliard? I met your friends, Orllensa and Ferras. Haliard?
I don't know.
Don't know what?
Who I am.
Look, if we find your friends
Doesn't matter who I am, who you are. The darkness will devour us all.
How?
They haven't gone away, you know. They're here, in this base. They're here. Here now.
The Cimmerians? The people who did this to you? What is it? What's the matter?
(scared) It's them.
Them?
I can hear them.
The Cimmerians? Where?
Oh no. No, no, no, no, no!
Runs off.
No, please, you can't just leave me here. Come. Oh.
Something sounds like it says Haliard.

Hello? Are you, are you a Cimmerian? Why did you do all this? Nearly blind me and burn out the other's eyes? I can see, you know. Maybe not very clearly, but you didn't finish the job off with me. My eyes are still working.
What are eyes?
What do you? (pause) They're what we see with when there's light.
We take the light.
I know. Why?
It is bad.
What are you doing?
You must embrace the darkness.
No. Get away from me. What are you doing?
Embrace it. It is good.
RAU 1 clomps in.
Lifeforms located. Engaging assault protocols.
You've got to help me!
Well, I'm very pleased to meet you, Mister Ferras. Tell me, was my friend Charley all right when she arrived?
Yeah, I think so. Wasn't she?
Yes. It was only she said the light was going, again.
And that's when she started to feel pain.
It was horrible. It was like going through it all over again.
Weapons fire and screaming at a distance.
What's going on?
That was Charley. Wait here!
Who's that firing?
Sounded like the ROSM unit to me. Ever met one before?
Er, no, I haven't. What are they like?
Well, let's just say, be thankful it's on your side.
The RAU 1 is shooting at something, then stops.
You are identified as lifeform Charley.
I may be feeling awful, but the one thing I'm not suffering from is an identity crisis, thank you.
Running feet stop.
Charley. ROSM, leave her alone. Charley, what happened? Who's that?
I think it's a Cimmerian, and I think our friendly robot here shot it.
Did you kill it?
High level disabling charge was applied. Unknown lifeform's life functions are being detected.
Good. Charley, let me see your eyes.
Oh, it's all right, it's all right. I've still got them. They're just not working very well. I take it you met the others?
Yes. What was this creature doing before ROSM arrived?
I'm not sure.
Did you talk to it?
Yes, but it was difficult to make out what it was saying.

The creature was releasing an energy field in the direction of lifeform Charley. This energy field contained particles significantly similar to those responsible for the damage to the Cimmeria Four Base lighting systems.
I see. So you were in fact rescuing lifeform Charley. Can I take it you no longer intend to terminate her?
She has been exposed to a possible alien threat. She has therefore become a vital piece of evidence in this investigation.
Well, that's nice to know. So you're not going to kill me.
I believe I have already answered that question.
Touchy, isn't he.
They have taken one of us prisoner.
2: Yes. They will take him from us. Discover our secrets. Bring suffering to our world again. They must never leave here.
Never. Is everything prepared?
2: Not yet. But the time approaches, and this time our power will be unstoppable. Their machines will not be able to restore the light.
Their own actions have brought this upon them.
2: Yes.
All exits to this control centre are now guarded by ROSM Assault Units. I will now examine lifeform Charley.
Er, Doctor?
It's all right, Charley. It is all right, isn't it, ROSM?
No harm will come to lifeform Charley.
Is that good enough for you, Charley?
I suppose it'll have to be.
Scan commencing now.
How are your eyes feeling?
I'm not sure. They don't hurt any more, and, and
Yes, go on.
Oh, I'm probably imagining it, but my eyesight seems to be a bit better.
Hmm.
I am imagining it, aren't I?
Very probably, unless ours are growing back.
Sorry.
Oh, for God's sake, don't pity us.
Orllensa, give her a break. Charley?
Yes?
You said you spoke to this, this Cimmerian creature.
Yes, it came right up to me.
What's it look like?
Oh, who cares! These Cimmerians obviously don't want us here. We need rescuing. The ROSM is here. Rescue Operational Security Module. Why aren't we being rescued?
I can't, I couldn't really see what it was like. Seemed quite featureless, but maybe that's just my eyesight. Is it still alive, Doctor?
The little fellow still seems to be breathing. And it wasn't just your eyesight, Charley. It does appear to possess a remarkably simple physiology.
Describe it to me.
Is it ugly? I hope so.
No, not at all. It looks child-like. It would stand no taller than your waist, whitish-grey skin, almost anaemic looking.
What about his face?
As sweet as a new born babe in arms. Oh, coochy, coochy, coo.
Again, very simple. Flat, almost invisible nose, small slit for a mouth. Dark flat eyes.
Eyes! That's it.
Yeah, don't remind us.
No, it asked me what eyes were. It didn't seem to know.
Interesting.
Oh, yes. Let's all sit round and have a debate about it. Hey you, ROSM, can't they do this aboard your ship on the way home?
Scan complete.
What are the results?
They are being assessed by my central processor aboard the ship.
Where we should be, you mean.
What about your friend Haliard, Orllensa? Do you want to just leave him behind?
What makes you think he's still alive? The darkness swallowed him up.
I spoke to him, Orllensa.
You spoke to him? Is he all right?
He's, well, I'm afraid I think he's a very disturbed individual, but far from being swallowed up.
I had an encounter with him too. The poor fellow needs expert help.
Join the club.
They can't find me. Never find me. I don't know who I am. Why do I exist? Is that you? There's someone near, isn't there. I can tell.
For you there is no light, but you cannot taste it.
What are you talking about? You shouldn't be talking to me. I don't exist.
You are hurt, creature.
Hurt? Hurt! (maniacal laugh.)
The laugh is heard here.
My God. That's him, isn't it.
Haliard.
Sounds like him.
Well, at least he's happy.

Hurt, eh? You burnt out my eyes. I heard them talking, you see. The others, when the girl arrived. We all thought you'd just hurt us and turned out the lights, but you burnt out our eyes! How, why should you want to do that?
Eyes? What are eyes?
What do you mean?
Let us taste.
What are you doing? No, no, no, stop it.
Eyes. Eyes. Let us taste your eyes.
No! No!
A long, long scream.
It's the Cimmerians, isn't it? They've got him.
What the hell are they doing to him?
Doctor?
Doctor. What is it with you? She seems to think you're the font of all human knowledge.
Orllensa, give it a rest.
Perhaps it's better than being the personification of sarcasm and bitterness.
And it's not just human knowledge, Orllensa.
Well then, what are they doing to Haliard?
I haven't the faintest idea, but I think we should find out.
No. My central processor has assessed this as a hostile attack situation. The remaining nineteen Roving Assault Units in the ship have been activated and will be arriving shortly.
You mean you're declaring war, or something?
It's about time.
ROSM, you're a sophisticated artificial intelligence. Surely you must know that contact with another species requires a little delicacy and

Security alternatives have priority. Base personnel's lives are protected by extended company warranty. I must act to protect and rescue them. You will all return to the safety of the ship immediately.
Sounds good to me. Leave it to the experts, I say.
You'd better lead the way, Doctor.
Charley, can you see well enough to take them back through the main airlock?
Yes. Yes, I think so.
Good. I'll stay here with ROSM. We need to find out what these Cimmerian creatures want.
To burn out your eyes. Isn't that obvious?
Yes, Orllensa, it is obvious. But in such cases as these, the obvious is rarely at the heart of the matter. Right, Charley, off you go and
Bang! from a RAU weapon.
Ah.
No, Doctor. You will go with the others.
Or what? You'll kill me?
Correct.
Oh. But that hardly seems fair.
(laughs) Not so clever after all.
Oh, shut up, Orllensa.
You are an alien intruder whose presence I am able to tolerate only as long as you do not contradict security imperatives.
RAU hydraulic sounds.
Doctor, more of them.
It's the cavalry.
You must all go now, Doctor. If you attempt to disobey again, there will be no further warning.
I wouldn't argue with it, Doctor.
Oh, what's the big man going to do now?
The sensible thing. Come on, Charley. I'll bring our Cimmerian guest with us.
You must be joking! ROSM, you can't allow him to
ROSM, you must acknowledge that this creature is vital to your investigation.
Agreed. But the ship's defence systems will terminate its life functions at the first sign of threat.
It is a threat. We should just dump it here and blast off.
Haliard must be rescued before departure is allowed.
But don't you think there's a good possibility these creatures have killed him?
Why do you people always assume the worst?
Because it's safer that way.
Not for your friend Haliard.
I'm detecting Haliard's life functions. He must be rescued. It is a central mission imperative.
Come on.
Haliard is in pain.
Argh! What are you doing to me?
Be still, creature. We have tasted your eyes.
What? What do you mean?
2: We have tasted your fear, creature.
We now know where your terror and pain are, creature.
2: We now know. Be still.
No, please! Noooo00000000!
Door opens. Footsteps.
Is that coffee I can smell?
You know, I think it is.
All the comforts of home in a ROSM rescue suite, Charley. Are the cushions green? I always remember the green.
Er, yes. Yes, they are. Very vivid, like pine trees.
Exactly how many times have you been rescued before, Orllensa?
A few. Why? Are you beginning to think I'm bad luck?
It had crossed my mind.
ROSM? ROSM, can you hear me? ROSM, do you have some kind of laboratory or medical facility where I can take a look at this Cimmerian? Hello? ROSM?
Probably too busy with his assault units, Doctor.
No, no, ROSM is multi-tasking, I'm sure of it. He should have ample processor power to talk to me as well.
Perhaps he just doesn't like your voice. Or your face.
ROSM! Charley, I'm going to the control deck. I'll leave the Cimmerian here. Can you wrap it in your coat? The poor thing feels very cold to me.
Oh, the poor thing.
I won't be long. See it doesn't come to any harm.
All right, Doctor. Now then, let's see if we can warm you up. There. Ah, there we are. Is that better?
What's the matter with you? That thing is dangerous.
It doesn't look dangerous. It looks. That's strange.
Oh, what? Has it grown another head?
It really does look like a helpless child.
You mean it is a child? That there might be adults about, bigger and nastier?
No, I mean I didn't notice before. I couldn't see so clearly before. I really do think my eyesight is getting better ever since. Ever since this creature spoke to me.
Assault units, you are now all in position. Proceed with search.
[OC]: Assault units twelve and fifteen report momentary visual contact with creatures matching known Cimmerian appearance.
I am detecting the release of more unknown particles in your area. This is to be interpreted as an attack.
[OC]: Understood. Cimmerian creatures sighted.
ROSM, what's happening? Why didn't you answer my calls?
Please be quiet, Doctor. An attack situation is in progress.
Oh well, far be it from me to interrupt a ROSM when he's busy playing war games.
What were you doing in your base?
What do you mean?
Well, why did you have a base on a planet in a place where there was no light?
Oh. Well, we were setting up the EPUs.
The EP? I take it that's an acronym for something.

What's it to you? If you're really that interested, you should listen to the standard recording of Professor Astrov's technical diatribe. If ROSM will let you. But don't ask Ferras. He never paid attention.
Oh, thanks, Orllensa. EPU stands for Energy Projection Units. We're about to fire up some artificial suns in orbit around this planet.
Ferras, just keep your mouth shut. Remember, we don't know who these people are.
But they helped us.
Only because they had a ROSM breathing down their necks. Just run along and play with your all-knowing Doctor friend, Charley. You're not wanted here.
Fair enough. Wouldn't want to outstay my welcome.
Good.

I know you don't want my pity, Orllensa, but I am sorry about what's happened to you and Ferras. Remember, it nearly happened to me too, so I know it really must be awful for you. But that doesn't stop me from thinking you're possibly the most obnoxious individual I've ever had the misfortune to meet!
Are you still here?
Lifeform Cimmerian, you will stand still.
We must take away the light.
You have committed an act of aggression by taking a member of base personnel captive. Return your captive immediately and surrender yourself for interrogation or immediate action will be taken.
Your creature, alien, must stay with us for now. That is our wish.
Unacceptable.
Weapons fire, scream then whimpers.
That was subtle.
All Assault Units proceed. Haliard must be located.
Come on, ROSM, you can't just blast your way through a whole civilisation to find one man. Hasn't humanity learnt anything about interfering with other cultures?
[OC]: Attention, attention. All Assault Units are reporting motor function difficulties.
Oh dear. Oh no.
Please explain.
I, I am unable to explain. All functions are being affected by unknown influence. All Assault Units register the same condition. Processor power reducing at an accelerating rate. (slowing) I cannot
Creaking metal then a final fizz. Crash of metal.
ROSM, you've got to get them out of there. ROSM, can you hear me?
I can, can hear you. Please, please do not interfere.
Are you all right?
(breathless) Doctor, I was right. My eyes really are
Wait a minute, Charley. Something bad is happening.
That sound.
You recognise it?
Yes, it's that sound when that little creature said to me, embrace the darkness.
ROSM, the Cimmerians are releasing their particles again. You must disengage your comm. link with the Assault Units. The particles could be transmitting along the waveband.
Disengaging. I, I am detecting unknown particles.
ROSM, listen to me. (sotto) I think it may be too late.
What's the matter with him?
Wait a minute. The particle analyser. I wonder if he'll let me operate it manually. Yes! There. You see that readout?
Yes, that's what I'm trying to tell you. I can see

It's the same particle signature ROSM detected when you were trapped in the base, before we landed. Hang on a minute. Oh, not quite the same. Anyway, it means the Cimmerians are releasing their light destroying particles again. ROSM, I think you are under threat. Disengage communication with the Assault Units!
Disengaging.
How do you feel now? Better?
I may have sustained some damage. I will run a diagnostic search. Please wait.
Doctor, are those particles, did they burn out Orllensa and Ferras's eyes?
I think so. Maybe it was a side-effect. Maybe it was deliberate. One thing is for certain. The Cimmerians don't like light.
But why not, if they have no eyes? Why should it bother them?
And what were they trying to do with these slightly different particles?
Destroy the ROSM's foot soldiers.
It would appear so. All Assault Units have suffered total breakdown of motor functions and cognitive abilities.
You mean they're dead? How many of these particles are there?
What are you getting at, Charley?
Well, if they're spreading, couldn't they get into this ship? I mean, through the door.
I am troubled that I have not come to this conclusion.
Have you finished your diagnostic search?
What diagnostic search?
Oh dear, he's not well, is he.
ROSM, your systems are under attack from unknown alien particles. Will you take some advice?
I will consider it.
Shut the main airlock and activate any defence shields you may have. ROSM?
Hello?
Hello. Who are you?
Oh no, it may be too late. There must be a way of operating his systems manually.
Manually? Or once a year.
Sonic screwdriver?

Sonic screwdriver. Charley, there's labelling on all these panels. Look for anything that reads override, manual or emergency. Preferably all three together. I've got to get into his main systems files, or we're going to find out exactly what these new unknown particles do first hand.
Orllensa? Orllensa?
Here. What.
When we get home, do you think. Do you think, well, I mean
Do I think they'll be able to make us see again?
Stupid, isn't it. Hoping.
Probably. Can you hear that?
It's that creature, isn't it. The Cimmerian.
Still breathing. We are sitting here with no eyes and that damn thing is still breathing!
Orllensa? Orllensa, what are you going to do?
Any luck?
No. You?
No. I was hoping we'd strike lucky. Oh well, just have to do it the hard way. Now I think this could be the main drive system. Let me see if I can get this inspection plate off. Hmm.
No luck?
Doctor, why are you attempting to damage peripheral hardware?
ROSM, how are you feeling? You recognise us now?
Only as a percentage probability of reality. I seem to be suffering from a systems breakdown.
I think alien particles are getting into this ship, into you. Can you shut the airlock door and activate your defence screens?
Since I am experiencing perceptual difficulties, I am not sure whether it is prudent to act.
In the absence of any other information, surely it can't do you any harm to protect yourself?
That is a persuasive argument
Have you done it?
Airlock door secured. Defensive shielding activated. I am recording a drop in the number of alien particles invading my systems. Cognitive abilities are improving.
Feeling better?
Ow! Doctor.
I have also placed lifeforms Doctor and Charley in containment fields until percentage probabilities of reality are more favourable.
I see. Best not to move, Charley.
I think I just worked that out for myself.
Beep beep beep.
Now what?
ROSM, what's happening?
Unknown particles are beginning to break through my defensive shielding. They are entering the ship.
Oh, I see.
What is it, Doctor?
It's suddenly occured to me.
What has?
That this is why no one has ever found out what happened to the Cimmerian sun.
But we know, don't we? These particles did it. For some reason, the Cimmerians released particles which swallowed up the light from their sun.

It seems that way, but this new wave of particles, they seem more powerful. They're actually attacking ROSM's systems, not just shutting off light. The first wave burnt out eyes. Who knows what the second wave do?
You mean the Cimmerians are trying to kill us?
We may have solved the mystery of the Cimmerian system, Charley, but it very much looks as if that information is going to die with us.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: Your dispersal beam seems to be working, if I'm reading these displays correctly.
ROSM: You are correct. But the dispersal rate is low.
DOCTOR: Yes, I see what you mean. Those unknown particles are pretty densely packed, aren't they?
ROSM: Lifeforms now detected.
DOCTOR: I can't make out the imaging. Is that three or four?
ROSM: Readings are still unclear. Unknown particle density is increasing.
DOCTOR: Can't you increase power to the dispersal beam?
ROSM: Not until landing has been effected. Initiating final descent.
FERRAS: (crying) My eyes! My eyes! Why did they do this?
ORLLENSA: Stop crying. Do you hear me? Stop it!
FERRAS: Sorry.
ORLLENSA: You'll end up like Haliard.
CHARLEY: Haliard? Who's Haliard?
ORLLENSA: The darkness took him.
CHARLEY: Took him? What do you mean?
ORLLENSA: I don't know what I mean! I've been driven half mad with pain. We both have. So that's how they did it. Burnt out our eyes.
FERRAS: The pain, it was indescribable.
CHARLEY: This is horrible.
ORLLENSA: It is for us. At least you can see. Is it dark everywhere? Did they take all the light?
CHARLEY: There only seems to be the light from that ship or whatever it is I arrived in. I can't see any other lights.
CHARLEY: Wait a minute.
FERRAS: What is it?
CHARLEY: I thought the light dimmed a bit just then.
FERRAS: Oh, no.
CHARLEY: What do you mean, oh no?
FERRAS: (scared) It's happening again!
CHARLEY: What's happening again?
ORLLENSA: They're taking your light, too.
CHARLEY: Who? Who is taking my light? Ah! It just dimmed again. Orllensa, who did this to you? Who is taking the light?
ORLLENSA: I don't know. The Cimmerians, I suppose you'd call them.
CHARLEY: Cimmerians? Fabled by the ancients to live in perpetual darkness. Ow!
FERRAS: What's the matter?
CHARLEY: Oh, my eyes. I felt
ORLLENSA: Pain.
CHARLEY: Ah! Oh, yes.
ORLLENSA: You have my pity, but there's nothing I can do.
CHARLEY: Nothing you can do about ow!
FERRAS: Orllensa, I can't bear it. I can't bear to hear her!
ORLLENSA: It's all we can do. Listen to her pain.
CHARLEY: Oh, oh, please no. Doctor!
DOCTOR: Come on, come on, come on.
ROSM: I find your impatience a curious response to the situation, lifeform Doctor, given you know I will terminate lifeform Charley when I have located her.
DOCTOR: But surely your primary mission is to rescue the personnel of the base?
ROSM: You are correct.
DOCTOR: Isn't it obvious that these alien particles.are more likely to pose a threat? What you've detected in Charley is potential mutagenic cells which may or may not turn malignant in the next few decades. Which is the more clear and present danger?
ROSM: Planetfall achieved. Particle dispersal beam intensity increasing to maximum. Lifepod is attached to secondary airlock. Extending docking connectors to Cimmeria Four Base main airlock.
DOCTOR: Are you ignoring me?
ROSM: There is still the matter of the unknown scan results. I'm considering my response.
DOCTOR: Take your time, ROSM, old chap. Take your time.
ROSM: Airlock connection achieved. Unknown particles now dispersed to minimal levels. You will accompany Roving Assault Unit One into the base.
DOCTOR: Can I have my sonic screwdriver back?
ROSM: I have analysed its capabilities and can now counteract them. You may have it back.
DOCTOR: You're too kind.
DOCTOR: Dark and foreboding. I'm beginning to feel right at home.
ROSM: You will remain in the light of the entrance while I attempt physical interface with the base's computer systems.
DOCTOR: Oh, back to Billy Goat Gruff, are we? Off you go, then.
DOCTOR: Charley! Charley, can you hear me? Charley? (sotto) Where are you?
DOCTOR: Hmm, night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day stands tiptoe on the misty mountain top. Well done, ROSM, old chap. You got the lights working.
ROSM: The computer systems were invaded by the same unknown particles. I have eradicated them.
DOCTOR: Good for you. I'm off to find lifeform Charley.
ROSM: You must wait here until the emergency situation can be assessed.
DOCTOR: ROSM, my best friend could be in trouble, so if you want to keep me here, you're just going to have to shoot me.
ROSM: That may yet be my preferred course of action, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Charley! Charley, it's the Doctor! Are you all right? Charley!
DOCTOR: Charley?
DOCTOR: That's not Charley. Who is that? Hello?
DOCTOR: We're here to help. Do you hear me? We're here to help. Listen to me. Listen, whoever you are.
DOCTOR: All right, now. Now show yourself. It's all right, we're here to help. What happened here? Tell me. What happened?
HALIARD: Embrace the darkness. Embrace the darkness. Embrace the darkness!
CIMMERIAN: They have brought the light.
CIMMERIAN: (The Cimmerians sound alike, and are only distinguished by which speaker their voices come from, left or right.)
CIMMERIAN: 2: Yes, they brought the light. They have destroyed our work.
CIMMERIAN: They try to kill us. They bring light.
CIMMERIAN: 2: We must take it again.
CIMMERIAN: We must.
CIMMERIAN: 2: Yes, yes, we must repair.
CIMMERIAN: Yes, they must all embrace the darkness.
CIMMERIAN: 2: Embrace the darkness or die.
DOCTOR: Hello? Dear God. Charley! Charley, it's the Doctor.
ORLLENSA: Hello.
DOCTOR: Oh. Hello. Was that you just now?
ORLLENSA: No. Haliard, I think.
DOCTOR: A friend of yours?
ORLLENSA: Yes. You said you're the Doctor.
DOCTOR: Er, yes. Yes, I am. Do you need a doctor?
ORLLENSA: I think I'm beyond that.
DOCTOR: What do you mean?
ORLLENSA: Come closer.
DOCTOR: Ah.
ORLLENSA: That's right. They took our eyes. The Cimmerians.
DOCTOR: The Cimmerians? I wasn't aware of such a species.
ORLLENSA: Well, someone did this to us, didn't they?
DOCTOR: Yes, yes, I suppose so. Listen to me. Have you seen?
ORLLENSA: Ha. You mean have I met your friend Charley?
DOCTOR: You have?
ORLLENSA: Talked to her, yes. She arrived just before you did. Broke the news to us.
DOCTOR: Broke the
ORLLENSA: Are you part of the rescue team?
DOCTOR: In a way, yes.
ORLLENSA: Where's the ROSM unit?
DOCTOR: Stomping around somewhere hereabouts. Can you take me to Charley?
ORLLENSA: I don't know.
DOCTOR: Why not?
ORLLENSA: She was in pain.
DOCTOR: In pain. Why?
ORLLENSA: It was her eyes. It was starting to happen again.
DOCTOR: What was?
ORLLENSA: I don't know. I don't know. I don't know anything!
DOCTOR: All right, all right, all right. I'm sorry.
ORLLENSA: No, I am. I find it difficult to think. I think I've gone insane.
DOCTOR: I wouldn't be too sure of that, if I were you. I've spent most of my life being told I'm mad.
ORLLENSA: You're very kind. Your friend Charley. She ran. I don't know how far. I can take you back to the secondary airlock reception, where we were. I think.
DOCTOR: Secondary airlock. We'll follow the signs. Take my arm, er, what's your name?
ORLLENSA: Orllensa.
DOCTOR: Orllensa, take my arm. So, come on.
CHARLEY: Oh. Oh. What happened? Where? Who are you?
CHARLEY: Who are you? I can't make out your face.
HALIARD: But you can see.
CHARLEY: Not very well. My eyes hurt.
HALIARD: Then they didn't succeed this time. But don't worry, they'll be back.
CHARLEY: Who? You mean the Cimmerians? Have you seen them?
HALIARD: You don't see them. Don't you understand? They take the light.
CHARLEY: Are you Haliard? I met your friends, Orllensa and Ferras. Haliard?
HALIARD: I don't know.
CHARLEY: Don't know what?
HALIARD: Who I am.
CHARLEY: Look, if we find your friends
HALIARD: Doesn't matter who I am, who you are. The darkness will devour us all.
CHARLEY: How?
HALIARD: They haven't gone away, you know. They're here, in this base. They're here. Here now.
CHARLEY: The Cimmerians? The people who did this to you? What is it? What's the matter?
HALIARD: (scared) It's them.
CHARLEY: Them?
HALIARD: I can hear them.
CHARLEY: The Cimmerians? Where?
HALIARD: Oh no. No, no, no, no, no!
CHARLEY: No, please, you can't just leave me here. Come. Oh.
CHARLEY: Hello? Are you, are you a Cimmerian? Why did you do all this? Nearly blind me and burn out the other's eyes? I can see, you know. Maybe not very clearly, but you didn't finish the job off with me. My eyes are still working.
CIMMERIAN: What are eyes?
CHARLEY: What do you? (pause) They're what we see with when there's light.
CIMMERIAN: We take the light.
CHARLEY: I know. Why?
CIMMERIAN: It is bad.
CHARLEY: What are you doing?
CIMMERIAN: You must embrace the darkness.
CHARLEY: No. Get away from me. What are you doing?
CIMMERIAN: Embrace it. It is good.
ROSM: Lifeforms located. Engaging assault protocols.
CHARLEY: You've got to help me!
DOCTOR: Well, I'm very pleased to meet you, Mister Ferras. Tell me, was my friend Charley all right when she arrived?
FERRAS: Yeah, I think so. Wasn't she?
ORLLENSA: Yes. It was only she said the light was going, again.
DOCTOR: And that's when she started to feel pain.
FERRAS: It was horrible. It was like going through it all over again.
ORLLENSA: What's going on?
DOCTOR: That was Charley. Wait here!
FERRAS: Who's that firing?
ORLLENSA: Sounded like the ROSM unit to me. Ever met one before?
FERRAS: Er, no, I haven't. What are they like?
ORLLENSA: Well, let's just say, be thankful it's on your side.
ROSM: You are identified as lifeform Charley.
CHARLEY: I may be feeling awful, but the one thing I'm not suffering from is an identity crisis, thank you.
DOCTOR: Charley. ROSM, leave her alone. Charley, what happened? Who's that?
CHARLEY: I think it's a Cimmerian, and I think our friendly robot here shot it.
DOCTOR: Did you kill it?
ROSM: High level disabling charge was applied. Unknown lifeform's life functions are being detected.
DOCTOR: Good. Charley, let me see your eyes.
CHARLEY: Oh, it's all right, it's all right. I've still got them. They're just not working very well. I take it you met the others?
DOCTOR: Yes. What was this creature doing before ROSM arrived?
CHARLEY: I'm not sure.
DOCTOR: Did you talk to it?
CHARLEY: Yes, but it was difficult to make out what it was saying.
ROSM: The creature was releasing an energy field in the direction of lifeform Charley. This energy field contained particles significantly similar to those responsible for the damage to the Cimmeria Four Base lighting systems.
DOCTOR: I see. So you were in fact rescuing lifeform Charley. Can I take it you no longer intend to terminate her?
ROSM: She has been exposed to a possible alien threat. She has therefore become a vital piece of evidence in this investigation.
CHARLEY: Well, that's nice to know. So you're not going to kill me.
ROSM: I believe I have already answered that question.
CHARLEY: Touchy, isn't he.
CIMMERIAN: They have taken one of us prisoner.
CIMMERIAN: 2: Yes. They will take him from us. Discover our secrets. Bring suffering to our world again. They must never leave here.
CIMMERIAN: Never. Is everything prepared?
CIMMERIAN: 2: Not yet. But the time approaches, and this time our power will be unstoppable. Their machines will not be able to restore the light.
CIMMERIAN: Their own actions have brought this upon them.
CIMMERIAN: 2: Yes.
ROSM: All exits to this control centre are now guarded by ROSM Assault Units. I will now examine lifeform Charley.
CHARLEY: Er, Doctor?
DOCTOR: It's all right, Charley. It is all right, isn't it, ROSM?
ROSM: No harm will come to lifeform Charley.
DOCTOR: Is that good enough for you, Charley?
CHARLEY: I suppose it'll have to be.
ROSM: Scan commencing now.
DOCTOR: How are your eyes feeling?
CHARLEY: I'm not sure. They don't hurt any more, and, and
DOCTOR: Yes, go on.
CHARLEY: Oh, I'm probably imagining it, but my eyesight seems to be a bit better.
DOCTOR: Hmm.
CHARLEY: I am imagining it, aren't I?
ORLLENSA: Very probably, unless ours are growing back.
CHARLEY: Sorry.
ORLLENSA: Oh, for God's sake, don't pity us.
FERRAS: Orllensa, give her a break. Charley?
CHARLEY: Yes?
FERRAS: You said you spoke to this, this Cimmerian creature.
CHARLEY: Yes, it came right up to me.
FERRAS: What's it look like?
ORLLENSA: Oh, who cares! These Cimmerians obviously don't want us here. We need rescuing. The ROSM is here. Rescue Operational Security Module. Why aren't we being rescued?
CHARLEY: I can't, I couldn't really see what it was like. Seemed quite featureless, but maybe that's just my eyesight. Is it still alive, Doctor?
DOCTOR: The little fellow still seems to be breathing. And it wasn't just your eyesight, Charley. It does appear to possess a remarkably simple physiology.
FERRAS: Describe it to me.
ORLLENSA: Is it ugly? I hope so.
DOCTOR: No, not at all. It looks child-like. It would stand no taller than your waist, whitish-grey skin, almost anaemic looking.
FERRAS: What about his face?
ORLLENSA: As sweet as a new born babe in arms. Oh, coochy, coochy, coo.
DOCTOR: Again, very simple. Flat, almost invisible nose, small slit for a mouth. Dark flat eyes.
CHARLEY: Eyes! That's it.
ORLLENSA: Yeah, don't remind us.
CHARLEY: No, it asked me what eyes were. It didn't seem to know.
DOCTOR: Interesting.
ORLLENSA: Oh, yes. Let's all sit round and have a debate about it. Hey you, ROSM, can't they do this aboard your ship on the way home?
ROSM: Scan complete.
DOCTOR: What are the results?
ROSM: They are being assessed by my central processor aboard the ship.
ORLLENSA: Where we should be, you mean.
CHARLEY: What about your friend Haliard, Orllensa? Do you want to just leave him behind?
ORLLENSA: What makes you think he's still alive? The darkness swallowed him up.
CHARLEY: I spoke to him, Orllensa.
FERRAS: You spoke to him? Is he all right?
CHARLEY: He's, well, I'm afraid I think he's a very disturbed individual, but far from being swallowed up.
DOCTOR: I had an encounter with him too. The poor fellow needs expert help.
ORLLENSA: Join the club.
HALIARD: They can't find me. Never find me. I don't know who I am. Why do I exist? Is that you? There's someone near, isn't there. I can tell.
CIMMERIAN: For you there is no light, but you cannot taste it.
HALIARD: What are you talking about? You shouldn't be talking to me. I don't exist.
CIMMERIAN: You are hurt, creature.
HALIARD: Hurt? Hurt! (maniacal laugh.)
FERRAS: My God. That's him, isn't it.
DOCTOR: Haliard.
CHARLEY: Sounds like him.
ORLLENSA: Well, at least he's happy.
HALIARD: Hurt, eh? You burnt out my eyes. I heard them talking, you see. The others, when the girl arrived. We all thought you'd just hurt us and turned out the lights, but you burnt out our eyes! How, why should you want to do that?
CIMMERIAN: Eyes? What are eyes?
HALIARD: What do you mean?
CIMMERIAN: Let us taste.
HALIARD: What are you doing? No, no, no, stop it.
CIMMERIAN: Eyes. Eyes. Let us taste your eyes.
HALIARD: No! No!
FERRAS: It's the Cimmerians, isn't it? They've got him.
ORLLENSA: What the hell are they doing to him?
CHARLEY: Doctor?
ORLLENSA: Doctor. What is it with you? She seems to think you're the font of all human knowledge.
FERRAS: Orllensa, give it a rest.
CHARLEY: Perhaps it's better than being the personification of sarcasm and bitterness.
DOCTOR: And it's not just human knowledge, Orllensa.
ORLLENSA: Well then, what are they doing to Haliard?
DOCTOR: I haven't the faintest idea, but I think we should find out.
ROSM: No. My central processor has assessed this as a hostile attack situation. The remaining nineteen Roving Assault Units in the ship have been activated and will be arriving shortly.
CHARLEY: You mean you're declaring war, or something?
ORLLENSA: It's about time.
DOCTOR: ROSM, you're a sophisticated artificial intelligence. Surely you must know that contact with another species requires a little delicacy and
ROSM: Security alternatives have priority. Base personnel's lives are protected by extended company warranty. I must act to protect and rescue them. You will all return to the safety of the ship immediately.
FERRAS: Sounds good to me. Leave it to the experts, I say.
ORLLENSA: You'd better lead the way, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Charley, can you see well enough to take them back through the main airlock?
CHARLEY: Yes. Yes, I think so.
DOCTOR: Good. I'll stay here with ROSM. We need to find out what these Cimmerian creatures want.
ORLLENSA: To burn out your eyes. Isn't that obvious?
DOCTOR: Yes, Orllensa, it is obvious. But in such cases as these, the obvious is rarely at the heart of the matter. Right, Charley, off you go and
DOCTOR: Ah.
ROSM: No, Doctor. You will go with the others.
DOCTOR: Or what? You'll kill me?
ROSM: Correct.
DOCTOR: Oh. But that hardly seems fair.
ORLLENSA: (laughs) Not so clever after all.
CHARLEY: Oh, shut up, Orllensa.
